newsitem.title: CANADA: VanCity seeks approval for Canada virtual bank.
newsitem.headline: VanCity seeks approval for Canada virtual bank.

text.p: Vancouver City Savings Credit Union said on Tuesday that it has applied for federal approval to open the country's first totally branchless bank, early next year.
The new bank, Citizens Bank of Canada, will enable customers to do all their banking over the telephone, computer, television or an automated teller machine.

"Citizens Bank...expects to open early in 1997, but there will be no lineups, no waiting, no tellers and no branches," VanCity said in a statement. VanCity is the latest company to join the race to set up virtual banking operations in Canada.
Earlier this summer, Dutch financial services giant ING Groep NV said it is planning to set up an electronic, branchless bank in Canada.
Last month, Trimark Financial Corp, AGF Management Ltd and Citibank Canada, a unit of Citicorp, said they also have plans to offer virtual banking services.

VanCity is Canada's largest credit union with nearly C$5 billion in assets and owns Citizens Trust. VanCity said it has sought federal approval to convert Citizens Trust's existing charter to national bank status.

VanCity said Citizens Bank will offer a full range of banking services, including savings and chequing accounts, term deposits, mortgage lending, retirement savings plans, bill payments and ATM services.
Citizens Bank chief executive officer Linda Crompton said the new bank will offer customers a branchless alternative to Canada's traditional banks.
"We believe that over time we will change the face of banking in this country," Crompton said.
